div1.head: Rendering TEI Documents for Traditional Consumption

div2.head: Simplfying Structure
div2.p: Humanities documents that are marked up with TEI can contain explicit information about many features of texts in many domains. Much of this analytical structure is not immediately relevant in the context of rendering the text for a reader. Consider a TEI text with annotations indicating the grammatical part of speech of each word. These annotations, while relevant in the context of a linguistic discussion of the text, would be distracting to a general reader who wants to interact with the narrative, unconcerned with syntax.

There are other aspects of TEI structure which are relevant for printing even in the general context, but which we currently set aside in the interest of producing a working product this summer. For example, some TEI texts contain rich indexical information about cannonical names of entities. This sort of information can be leveraged to create an appendicies for a printed text which allow a reader to look up the page numbers where certain words or topics are discussed.

Finally, printed media bring their own set of constraints on what can be represented. For example, traditional typesetting in Latin based alphabets provides alternative glyph shapes (for example, italics) which an author can use to indicate distinctions in the text. But there are only a only a small number of alternative glyph shapes and we can imagine a TEI document which encodes a large set of distinct information types. While the particular constraints of a rendered medium differ from instance to instance (consider HTML in a browser vs ink on a page), the point here is that all cases require a simplification of the structures available in TEI.

To sum up, printing a TEI document for a general reader requires a simplification of structure. The complete TEI provides more information than can be squeezed onto a page designed to emphasize the orginal narrative. For these reasons, the electronic publication group within NDTH has selected a subset of TEI structures to support in our work for summer 2013. The rest of this document illustrates those structures and presents the formatting associated with each structure.
div2.note: Some Latin-based fonts include monospace, italic, bold, small caps, perhaps a few other variants. However, a document which used very many of these alternatives to represent up meta-textual features runs the risk of distracting the general reader from the content of the narrative.

div2.p: The content of TEI documents is contained in an <text> element. This element can contain <front> and <back> elements, alongside a required <body>.

div2.head: <front>
div2.p: Within the <front> element, the printing methods we are developing will look for title page information within the <titlePage> element (if present). For the moment, we support <titlePart> and <byline> within <titlePage>.

div2.head: <body>
div2.p: Within the <body> our methods will support two levels of text structure. These are <div1> and <div2>. in the case of diaries the <div1> will probably represent collections of diary entries ('chapters', or 'journies' or 'months' for example). <div2> will be individual diary entries.
<pb n="1" /> is the page break element, which is a milestone marker to show page divisions within a document. The "n" attribute identifies the page numbers of the original document.

<lb n="1" /> is the line break element, which is a milestone marker to show line divisions within a prose document. The "n" attribute identifies the line numbers of the original document. Line breaks and line break numbers will not be represented in the output. Prose text will be presented as flowing paragraphs.
<lg> is used to indicate verse groups such as stanzas. <l> is used to indicate individual lines of verse. These lines will be retained in output.

lg.l: Its fleece was white as snow

div2.p: Drawings in the original documents should be indicated using the following elements. The drawing, a caption, and the file name of the image are identified by the figure, head, and graphic elements. In the output, only the image file name will be displayed.
Lists may include passagers, cargo, relatives, etc.: <list> <item>Antone Marine</item> <item>Eliza, my wife</item> </list>
Documents may contain tables, such as train schedules: ArriveDepart

Commonly used content elements include <name>Alexander Svoboda </name> and <foreign>??????????????????</foreign> words and phrases. Our practice is to use <foreign> to represent scripts and languages other than the source text.
div2.name: Alexander Svoboda
div2.note: Note here about multilingual config: div1 (container) then: div2,div3.

Note that texts can still use the @type attribute to further specify types of <div1>,<div2>,<head>, etc. It's just that for now the automatic printing processes aren't going to do anything about that info if it's present.
